i cant say this will be everyones experience but for me retro arch has always worked butter smooth and almost RTR with all versions of OS and distros ive tried inc arch linux,backtrack linux, the steam deck/steamOS and android on a motorola edge 20 pro (ideally with retroarch on aphone,you need a good lot of memory and a high numbered snap dragon cpu.), i recomend it to anyone but especially those new to emulation,just download the cores you want on the frontend and the rest,is as they say...history.

description: Configuring emulators is a science of its own. RetroArch makes this as easy as possible. However, don't expect it to *just* work. You will require some fiddling around to make it fly. I recommend to *not* use libretro cores and other stuff like assests from your distribution but instead use the download feature of retroarch. It is just way more convenient.
I hate the ui, why?
This is the wrong version. You are now suffering from the dumb.

Install this from the snap store from terminal: 

To see which version:
snap find retroarch

To install from snap:
sudo snap install retroarch

Or download directly from the godot website if you do not run snaps for a newer version with many fixes and quality of life updates.

If you hate the UI press F5 to open the QT front-end that is built in now. This can also be set to always start up in settings under video.

description:
although, in term of performance, some cores is slower compared to other more specialized emulators. 
like in my case, i can get full speed playing psx games using epsxe but in retroarch it's so slow, like at least twice as slow.
but since im playing it in an old hardware maybe others with good hardware won't notice this slow down at all.

also for those who are having trouble, 'core updater' can actually be enabled in the settings, just make sure you set the cores folder to a non-root writable location for retroarch to be able to write the downloaded cores, obviously.

It's pretty simple. Essentially, this page on Discover isn't complete. You have to add a repository that can be used to install the cores via APT:

sudo add-apt-repository ppa:libretro/testing && sudo apt-get update && sudo apt-get install retroarch*

Or you could do what I did and install the Flatpak version. Other than that, it's a solid version of RetroArch!

Much more than a frontend.
BEWARE: 
This is the older stable version which can't update cores online only manually.
For online updates use the testing ppa and purge the older installation.

Most retroarch usually come with downloadable cores right after when you boot up the software unless if you're doing it on console.

However for whatever reason, this retroarch doesn't have the option to download cores from the software. Also my other complaint is that this software is outdated (1.7.3), but on the website or flathub, they both have the updated version which is 1.9.0. You're better off getting retroarch from it's website or simply flathub. It has a menu driver that doesn't slow down any low-end computer.
summary: For the love of god, do not get this

description:
For those of you struggling to figure out how to install cores (like I was), here is an easy way to work around it, just install RetroArch using snap instead. Open the terminal and type: sudo snap install retroarch

It will install the snap version of RetroArch which allows you to download cores from online. There is also a great Youtube video about it here: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=8QLpkRgeR-I

Hope this helps!
Look up some online tutorials for setting up cores and changing settings. If you are a retro gamer this is worth your time.
good application for emulation, download it you won't reget playing psp, gameboy games and other platforms!

First off let me say I appreciate all the work of the ORIGINAL emulator authors. Without them RetroArch wouldn't exist. Next I love how RetroArch wraps everything into one interface. It's a confusing interface, but an interface none the less. With loading the cores then loading the ROMs then starting the emulator it's a bit much for new users. At least there is the Ozone menu driver to make it feel familiar to Nintendo Switch users. Anyway, great package. Thank You.

Takes some time and effort to learn to use this complex emulation environment, but it's really worth it. Once you get the hang of it, everything makes sense and is easy to find and use. It is a big project, no doubt, so take it easy at the beginning - it can be quite frustrating at first. But it will be worth it!

Definitely check out the Android version as well, if you haven't already?️

description: By far the most extensive front-end to different emulators. However, it is far from perfect as it will not run some roms. In this respect FCEUX is better (for NES as an example), PCSXR is better for PS1, PCSX2 is the only option for PS2 while there are no better alternatives for Sega Genesis. With that said, you'll be very happy RetroArch and I'll be surprise if you don't.

If you want your retrogames in a pretty interface, RetroArch delivers. Their "cores" are not as extensive as I would like (Higan is better in this regard), but otherwise it's a very solid front-end emulator.
Seemed a bit complicated but it was really easy, worked like a charm.

After a hour of moving in circles i was so confused that i give up. Its easier for me to download, install and configure several emulators in directories of their own and use them at will. For me, RetroArch seems to be the product of Windows 10 or automotive gui designers.

He podido correr roms de Atari, NES (Nintendo Entertainment System), PS1 (Play Station 1) entre otros que están hackeados. 

Lo que no me gustó fue que la configuración si cambias ciertas cosas, no las vas a poder deshacer, si ya lo hiciste no hay marcha atrás, así como los emuladores, ya que si los extraes no los vas a poder borrar a menos que desinstales y vuelvas a instalar Retroarch, así que debes de tener cuidado con lo que descargas y cambias. Por cierto, de nada sirve que lo vuelvas a poner a configuración de fabrica porque te pone en ingles todo y se pierde la liga de la carpeta personal de tu computadora y solo ubicándola desde la root encontrarás tu carpeta. 

Por cierto, debes de ser muy preciso con el emulador que usas para que los puedas correr, pues si no son del emulador que necesita la rom, te mandará error o se cerrará la aplicación.

Tal vez esta sea una de las sugerencias que menos sirve, pues se supone que cada uno de los distritos linux tienen su soporte técnico; este programa no funciona, al instalarlo de cualquier manera, siendo la versión nightly, que anteriormente funcionaba, ahora a dejado de cargar los núcleos, pues hace rato que trabajo con un CPU Atom 1.6 GHz y 2 Gb de ram en la cual ya había instalado, tiene errores, sí, pero no los tenia hasta hacerlo inservible, ademas no sé a quien más acudir; hay una pagina en español muy buena que se llama ubunlog.com, ahí ayudan a configurar tu ubuntu, o derivados. El punto es que junto con esta paginas y algunas otras mencionan que las computadoras de pocos recursos ya no está funcionando el VIDEO, sobretodo en linux, es uno de los factores que casi no se recupera, yo podría pensar que es por antigüedad del CPU, pero hasta la fecha actual encuentras en el mercado PC con estos recursos, esto pensando que se supone son LTS o estables, solo espero que al comprar el servicio de soporte técnico estos problemas no sucedan.
